trans-unit.source: Managing Current Location
trans-unit.target: Managing Current Location

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: Managing Current Location
trans-unit.target: Managing Current Location

trans-unit.source: When navigating folder systems in File Explorer, you usually have a specific working location - namely, the current open folder.
trans-unit.target: When navigating folder systems in File Explorer, you usually have a specific working location - namely, the current open folder.

trans-unit.source: Items in the current folder can be manipulated easily by clicking them.
trans-unit.target: Items in the current folder can be manipulated easily by clicking them.

trans-unit.source: For command-line interfaces such as Cmd.exe, when you are in the same folder as a particular file, you can access it by specifying a relatively short name, rather than needing to specify the entire path to the file.
trans-unit.target: For command-line interfaces such as Cmd.exe, when you are in the same folder as a particular file, you can access it by specifying a relatively short name, rather than needing to specify the entire path to the file.

trans-unit.source: The current directory is called the working directory.
trans-unit.target: The current directory is called the working directory.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell uses the noun **Location** to refer to the working directory, and implements a family of cmdlets to examine and manipulate your location.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell uses the noun **Location** to refer to the working directory, and implements a family of cmdlets to examine and manipulate your location.

trans-unit.source: Getting Your Current Location (Get-Location)
trans-unit.target: Getting Your Current Location (Get-Location)

trans-unit.source: To determine the path of your current directory location, enter the **Get-Location** command:
trans-unit.target: To determine the path of your current directory location, enter the **Get-Location** command:

trans-unit.source: The Get-Location cmdlet is similar to the **pwd** command in the BASH shell.
trans-unit.target: The Get-Location cmdlet is similar to the **pwd** command in the BASH shell.

trans-unit.source: The Set-Location cmdlet is similar to the **cd** command in Cmd.exe.
trans-unit.target: The Set-Location cmdlet is similar to the **cd** command in Cmd.exe.

trans-unit.source: Setting Your Current Location (Set-Location)
trans-unit.target: Setting Your Current Location (Set-Location)

trans-unit.source: The **Get-Location** command is used with the **Set-Location** command.
trans-unit.target: The **Get-Location** command is used with the **Set-Location** command.

trans-unit.source: The **Set-Location** command allows you to specify your current directory location.
trans-unit.target: The **Set-Location** command allows you to specify your current directory location.

trans-unit.source: After you enter the command, you will notice that you do not receive any direct feedback about the effect of the command.
trans-unit.target: After you enter the command, you will notice that you do not receive any direct feedback about the effect of the command.

trans-unit.source: Most Windows PowerShell commands that perform an action produce little or no output because the output is not always useful.
trans-unit.target: Most Windows PowerShell commands that perform an action produce little or no output because the output is not always useful.

trans-unit.source: To verify that a successful directory change has occurred when you enter the **Set-Location** command, include the **-PassThru** parameter when you enter the **Set-Location** command:
trans-unit.target: To verify that a successful directory change has occurred when you enter the **Set-Location** command, include the **-PassThru** parameter when you enter the **Set-Location** command:

trans-unit.source: The **-PassThru** parameter can be used with many Set commands in Windows PowerShell to return information about the result in cases in which there is no default output.
trans-unit.target: The **-PassThru** parameter can be used with many Set commands in Windows PowerShell to return information about the result in cases in which there is no default output.

trans-unit.source: You can specify paths relative to your current location in the same way as you would in most UNIX and Windows command shells.
trans-unit.target: You can specify paths relative to your current location in the same way as you would in most UNIX and Windows command shells.

trans-unit.source: In standard notation for relative paths, a period (**.**)represents your current folder, and a doubled period (**..**) represents the parent directory of your current location.
trans-unit.target: In standard notation for relative paths, a period (**.**)represents your current folder, and a doubled period (**..**) represents the parent directory of your current location.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you are in the **C:\\Windows** folder, a period (**.**)represents **C:\\Windows** and double periods (**..**) represent **C:**.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you are in the **C:\\Windows** folder, a period (**.**)represents **C:\\Windows** and double periods (**..**) represent **C:**.

trans-unit.source: You can change from your current location to the root of the C: drive by typing:
trans-unit.target: You can change from your current location to the root of the C: drive by typing:

trans-unit.source: PS> Set-Location -Path ..
trans-unit.target: PS> Set-Location -Path ..

trans-unit.source: -PassThru Path ---- C:\
trans-unit.target: -PassThru Path ---- C:\

trans-unit.source: The same technique works on Windows PowerShell drives that are not file system drives, such as **HKLM:**.
trans-unit.target: The same technique works on Windows PowerShell drives that are not file system drives, such as **HKLM:**.

trans-unit.source: You can set your location to the HKLM\\Software key in the registry by typing:
trans-unit.target: You can set your location to the HKLM\\Software key in the registry by typing:

trans-unit.source: You can then change the directory location to the parent directory, which is the root of the Windows PowerShell HKLM: drive, by using a relative path:
trans-unit.target: You can then change the directory location to the parent directory, which is the root of the Windows PowerShell HKLM: drive, by using a relative path:

trans-unit.source: You can type Set-Location or use any of the built-in Windows PowerShell aliases for Set-Location (cd, chdir, sl).
trans-unit.target: You can type Set-Location or use any of the built-in Windows PowerShell aliases for Set-Location (cd, chdir, sl).

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Saving and Recalling Recent Locations (Push-Location and Pop-Location)
trans-unit.target: Saving and Recalling Recent Locations (Push-Location and Pop-Location)

trans-unit.source: When changing locations, it is helpful to keep track of where you have been and to be able to return to your previous location.
trans-unit.target: When changing locations, it is helpful to keep track of where you have been and to be able to return to your previous location.

trans-unit.source: The **Push-Location** cmdlet in Windows PowerShell creates a ordered history (a "stack") of directory paths where you have been, and you can step back through the history of directory paths by using the complementary **Pop-Location** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The **Push-Location** cmdlet in Windows PowerShell creates a ordered history (a "stack") of directory paths where you have been, and you can step back through the history of directory paths by using the complementary **Pop-Location** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For example, Windows PowerShell typically starts in the user's home directory.
trans-unit.target: For example, Windows PowerShell typically starts in the user's home directory.

trans-unit.source: The word *stack* has a special meaning in many programming settings, including .NET Framework.
trans-unit.target: The word *stack* has a special meaning in many programming settings, including .NET Framework.

trans-unit.source: Like a physical stack of items, the last item you put onto the stack is the first item that you can pull off the stack.
trans-unit.target: Like a physical stack of items, the last item you put onto the stack is the first item that you can pull off the stack.

trans-unit.source: Adding an item to a stack is colloquially known as "pushing" the item onto the stack.
trans-unit.target: Adding an item to a stack is colloquially known as "pushing" the item onto the stack.

trans-unit.source: Pulling an item off the stack is colloquially known as "popping" the item off the stack.
trans-unit.target: Pulling an item off the stack is colloquially known as "popping" the item off the stack.

trans-unit.source: To push the current location onto the stack, and then move to the Local Settings folder, type:
trans-unit.target: To push the current location onto the stack, and then move to the Local Settings folder, type:

trans-unit.source: You can then push the Local Settings location onto the stack and and move to the Temp folder by typing:
trans-unit.target: You can then push the Local Settings location onto the stack and and move to the Temp folder by typing:

trans-unit.source: You can verify that you changed directories by entering the **Get-Location** command:
trans-unit.target: You can verify that you changed directories by entering the **Get-Location** command:

trans-unit.source: You can then pop back into the most recently visited directory by entering the **Pop-Location** command, and verify the change by entering the **Get-Location** command:
trans-unit.target: You can then pop back into the most recently visited directory by entering the **Pop-Location** command, and verify the change by entering the **Get-Location** command:

trans-unit.source: Just as with the **Set-Location** cmdlet, you can include the **-PassThru** parameter when you enter the **Pop-Location** cmdlet to display the directory that you entered:
trans-unit.target: Just as with the **Set-Location** cmdlet, you can include the **-PassThru** parameter when you enter the **Pop-Location** cmdlet to display the directory that you entered:

trans-unit.source: You can also use the Location cmdlets with network paths.
trans-unit.target: You can also use the Location cmdlets with network paths.

trans-unit.source: If you have a server named FS01 with an share named Public, you can change your location by typing
trans-unit.target: If you have a server named FS01 with an share named Public, you can change your location by typing

trans-unit.source: or
trans-unit.target: or

trans-unit.source: You can use the **Push-Location** and **Set-Location** commands to change the location to any available drive.
trans-unit.target: You can use the **Push-Location** and **Set-Location** commands to change the location to any available drive.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have a local CD-ROM drive with drive letter D that contains a data CD, you can change the location to the CD drive by entering the **Set-Location D:** command.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have a local CD-ROM drive with drive letter D that contains a data CD, you can change the location to the CD drive by entering the **Set-Location D:** command.

trans-unit.source: If the drive is empty, you will get the following error message:
trans-unit.target: If the drive is empty, you will get the following error message:

trans-unit.source: When you are using a command-line interface, it is not convenient to use File Explorer to examine the available physical drives.
trans-unit.target: When you are using a command-line interface, it is not convenient to use File Explorer to examine the available physical drives.

trans-unit.source: Also, File Explorer would not show you the all of the Windows PowerShell drives.
trans-unit.target: Also, File Explorer would not show you the all of the Windows PowerShell drives.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell provides a set of commands for manipulating Windows PowerShell drives, and we will talk about these next.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell provides a set of commands for manipulating Windows PowerShell drives, and we will talk about these next.
